Next, we present TheoremÂ 2 and justify how FLAME design reduces the derived noise level with step 3 (S3) below.

(S3) Clustering and clipping components in FLAME help to reduce the DP noise boundary. Recall that FLAME protects the FL system against backdoor attacks using three steps: clustering, clipping, and adding DP noise. The overall workflow of FLAME is shown in Fig.Â 4. If multiple backdoors exist in the FL system, the first two steps (clustering and clipping) can remove a subset of backdoors as shown in Fig.Â 3a. Note that the remaining backdoors are â€˜closerâ€™ to the benign model updates in terms of both magnitude and direction. This gives us the intuition that removing the remaining backdoors by adding DP noise becomes easier (i.e., the noise scale ÏƒGsubscriptğœğº\sigma_{G} is smaller) after the first two steps of FLAME.

We can see from TheoremÂ 1 that the Gaussian noise scale Ïƒğœ\sigma required for backdoor resilience increases with the sensitivity of each local model Î”isubscriptÎ”ğ‘–\Delta_{i}. We describe two characteristics of the model parameter Wğ‘ŠW, i.e., direction and magnitude in Â§4. We discuss how these two factors impact the sensitivity of the model defined in Eq.Â 4 below.

Theorem 2.

Backdoor models with large angular deviation from benign ones, or with large parameter magnitudes have high sensitivity values Î”Î”\Delta.

Proving DP-based backdoor security for DNN models is still an open problem, even in the centralized setting. We, therefore, adopt a common approach in literature (e.g., [19]) by providing theoretical proof for linear models and validating it for DNNs empirically.

Proof: for a linear model fğ‘“f where the function output is determined by the inner product of model weight vector wâ†’â†’ğ‘¤\overrightarrow{w} and the data vector xâ†’â†’ğ‘¥\overrightarrow{x}, we have

fâ€‹(w;x)=wâ†’â‹…xâ†’=|w|â‹…|x|â‹…câ€‹oâ€‹sâ€‹Î¸,ğ‘“ğ‘¤ğ‘¥â‹…â†’ğ‘¤â†’ğ‘¥â‹…ğ‘¤ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ ğœƒf(w;~{}x)=\overrightarrow{w}\cdot\overrightarrow{x}=|w|\cdot|x|\cdot cos\theta,\vspace{-0.5em} (8)

where Î¸=<wâ†’,xâ†’>\theta=<\overrightarrow{w},\overrightarrow{x}> is the angle between two vectors. In this case, it is straightforward to see that if the backdoor attack changes the parameter magnitude |w|ğ‘¤|w| or the direction Î¸ğœƒ\theta of the model fğ‘“f, the resulting poisoned model fâ€²superscriptğ‘“â€²f^{\prime} has a large sensitivity value based on the definition in Eq.Â 4. âˆ

This analysis suggests that backdoor models with large angular deviations or with large weight magnitudes have a high sensitivity value Î”Î”\Delta. Recall that FLAME deploys dynamic clustering (Â§4.3.1) to remove poisoned models with large cosine distances, and employs adaptive clipping (Â§4.3.2) to remove poisoned models with large magnitudes. Therefore, the sensitivity of the remaining backdoor models is lower compared to the one before applying these two steps. As a result, FLAME can use a small Gaussian noise to eliminate the remaining backdoors after applying clustering and clipping, which is beneficial for preserving the main task accuracy.

We empirically show how the noise scale for backdoor elimination changes after applying each step of FLAME. Particularly, we measure the smallest Gaussian noise scale Ïƒğœ\sigma required to defeat all backdoors (i.e., Bâ€‹A=0%ğµğ´percent0BA=0\%) in three settings: i) No defense components applied (which is equivalent to the previous DP-based defenseÂ [20, 9]); ii) After applying dynamic clustering; iii) After applying both dynamic clustering and adaptive clipping (which is the setting of FLAME). We conduct this comparison experiment on the IoT-Traffic dataset (cf.Â Â§6). For each communication round, 100 clients are selected where k=40ğ‘˜40k=40 are adversaries. We remove the backdoor by adding Gaussian noise Nâ€‹(0,Ïƒ2)ğ‘0superscriptğœ2{N}(0,\sigma^{2}) to the aggregated model. TableÂ 1 summarizes the evaluation results in the above three settings. We can observe from the comparison results that the noise scale required to eliminate backdoors decreases after individual deployment of clustering and clipping. This corroborates the correctness of TheoremÂ 2.

5.2 Attack and Data Distribution Assumption

In FLAME, we do not make specific assumptions about the attack and data distribution compared to the existing clustering-based defenses. Let X=(X1,â€¦,Xb)ğ‘‹subscriptğ‘‹1â€¦subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘X=(X_{1},\ldots,X_{b}) be a set of distributions of benign models (W1,â€¦,Wnâˆ’k)subscriptğ‘Š1â€¦subscriptğ‘Šğ‘›ğ‘˜(W_{1},\ldots,W_{n-k}) where bâ‰¤nâˆ’kğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘˜b\leq n-k. The deviation in Xğ‘‹X is caused by the diversity of the data. Let Xâ€²=(X1â€²,â€¦,Xaâ€²)superscriptğ‘‹â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‹â€²1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‹â€²ğ‘X^{\prime}=(X^{\prime}_{1},\ldots,X^{\prime}_{a}) be a set of distributions of poisoned models (W1â€²,â€¦,Wkâ€²)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šâ€²1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šâ€²ğ‘˜(W^{\prime}_{1},\ldots,W^{\prime}_{k}) where aâ‰¤kğ‘ğ‘˜a\leq k. The deviation in Xâ€²superscriptğ‘‹â€²X^{\prime} is caused by the diversity of the benign data and backdoors (e.g., poisoned data or model crafting). Existing works assume that Xiâ€²â‰ˆXjâ€²(âˆ€i,j:1â‰¤i,jâ‰¤a)X^{\prime}_{i}\approx X^{\prime}_{j}\quad(\forall i,j:1\leq i,j\leq a) (see e.g., [25] or Xâ€²â‰ Xsuperscriptğ‘‹â€²ğ‘‹X^{\prime}\neq X [56, 11]). However, this assumption does not hold in many situations because (i) there can be one or multiple attackers injecting multiple backdoorsÂ [9], or (ii) the adversary can inject one or several random (honeypot) models having a distribution Xrâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‹â€²ğ‘ŸX^{\prime}_{r} that is significantly different from Xâˆª(Xâ€²âˆ–Xrâ€²)ğ‘‹superscriptğ‘‹â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‹â€²ğ‘ŸX\cup(X^{\prime}\setminus X^{\prime}_{r}), and (iii) the adversary can control how much the backdoored models deviate from benign ones as discussed in Â§3. Therefore, approaches that purely divide models into two groups, e.g., K-meansÂ [56] will incorrectly classify models having distribution Xrâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‹â€²ğ‘ŸX^{\prime}_{r} into the malicious group and all remaining models (having distributions drawn from (Xâˆª(Xâ€²âˆ–Xrâ€²)ğ‘‹superscriptğ‘‹â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‹â€²ğ‘ŸX\cup(X^{\prime}\setminus X^{\prime}_{r})) into the benign group. As a result, all backdoored models having distributions drawn from (Xâ€²âˆ–Xrâ€²superscriptğ‘‹â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‹â€²ğ‘ŸX^{\prime}\setminus X^{\prime}_{r}) are classified as benign, as demonstrated in Fig. 5b. In contrast, FLAME does not rely on such specific assumptions (the adversary can arbitrarily choose Xâ€²superscriptğ‘‹â€²X^{\prime}). If the distribution Xiâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‹â€²ğ‘–X^{\prime}_{i} of a poisoned model is similar to benign distributions in Xğ‘‹X, FLAME will falsely classify Xiâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‹â€²ğ‘–X^{\prime}_{i} as being. But if the distribution Xjâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‹â€²ğ‘—X^{\prime}_{j} of a poisoned model is different from the distributions in Xğ‘‹X, FLAME will identify Xjâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‹â€²ğ‘—X^{\prime}_{j} as an outlier and classify the associated model as malicious. To identify deviating and thus potentially malicious models, FLAME leverages the HDBSCAN algorithm to identify regions of high density in the model space. Any models that are not located in the dense regions will be categorized as outliers, as shown in Fig.Â 5d. As discussed in Â§3, FLAME aims to remove models with distributions Xjâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‹â€²ğ‘—X^{\prime}_{j} that have a higher attack impact compared to models with distribution Xiâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‹â€²ğ‘–X^{\prime}_{i}. It is worth noting, however, that the impact of such remaining backdoored models will be eliminated by the noising component as shown in Â§5.1

Striking a balance between accuracy and security: Clustering and DP-based approaches affect model accuracy as discussed in Â§4.2 (Challenges C2subscriptğ¶2C_{2} and C3subscriptğ¶3C_{3}). In particular, an approach that aims to maximize the number of filtered malicious models may lead to many false positives, i.e., many benign models being filtered out. Moreover, applying a very low clipping bound or a very high level of injected noise will degrade model accuracy. To address these problems, FLAME is configured so that the clustering component removes only models with high attack impact rather than all malicious models, i.e., it aims to remove the first backdoor type W1â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šâ€²1W^{\prime}_{1} as shown in Fig. 3. In addition, FLAME carefully estimates the clipping bound and noise level to ensure backdoor elimination while preserving model performance. As discussed in Â§4.3.2, the L2-norms of model updates depend on the number of training rounds, dataset types, and type of backdoors. Consequently, the clipping threshold and noise level should be adapted to L2-norms. We therefore apply the median of the L2-norms of model updates as the clipping bound Stsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡S_{t} (cf. Lines 9-11 of Alg. 1). This ensures that Stsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡S_{t} is always computed between a benign local model and the global model since we assume that more than 50% of clients are benign (cf. Â§2.3). Further, estimating noise level based on Stsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡S_{t} (cf. Lines 13-14 of Alg. 1) also provides a noise boundary that ensures that the global model is resilient against backdoors as discussed in Â§5.1. Moreover, our comparison of potential values for Stsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡S_{t} presented in Â§B.2 and Â§B.3 shows that the chosen clipping bound and noise level provide the best balance between accuracy and security, i.e., FLAME eliminates backdoor while retaining the global modelâ€™s performance on the main task.

6 Experimental Setup

We conduct all the experiments using the PyTorch deep learning frameworkÂ [3] and use the source code provided by Bagdasaryan etÂ al.Â [9], Xie etÂ al.Â [64] and Wang etÂ al.Â [62] to implement the attacks. We reimplemented existing defenses to compare them with FLAME.

Datasets and Learning Configurations. Following recent research on poisoning attacks on FL, we evaluate FLAME in three typical application scenarios: word predictionÂ [43, 42, 44, 39], image classificationÂ [54, 55, 15], and an IoT intrusion detectionÂ [48, 52, 53, 59] as summarized in Tab. 6. Verification of the effectiveness of FLAME against state-of-the-art attacks in comparison to existing defenses (cf. Tab. 2 and Tab. 3) are conducted on these three datasets in the mentioned application scenarios. Experiments for evaluating specific performance aspects of FLAME are performed on the IoT dataset as it represents a very diverse and real-world setting with clear security implications.

Evaluation Metrics. We consider a set of metrics for evaluating the effectiveness of backdoor attack and defense techniques as follows:
BA - Backdoor Accuracy indicates the accuracy of the model in the backdoor task, i.e., it is the fraction of the trigger set for which the model provides the wrong outputs as chosen by the adversary. The adversary aims to maximize ğµğ´ğµğ´\mathit{BA}, while an effective defense prevents the adversary from increasing it.
MA - Main Task Accuracy indicates the accuracy of a model in its main (benign) task. It denotes the fraction of benign inputs for which the system provides correct predictions. The adversary aims at minimizing the effect on ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘€ğ´\mathit{MA} to reduce the chance of being detected. The defense system should not negatively impact ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘€ğ´\mathit{MA}.
TPR - True Positive Rate indicates how well the defense identifies poisoned models, i.e., the ratio of the number of models correctly classified as poisoned (True Positives - TP) to the total number of models being classified as poisoned: ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘…=Tâ€‹PTâ€‹P+Fâ€‹Pğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘…ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ¹ğ‘ƒ\mbox{$\mathit{TPR}$}=\frac{TP}{TP+FP}, where FP is False Positives indicating the number of benign clients that are wrongly classified as malicious. TNR - True Negative Rate indicates the ratio of the number of models correctly classified as benign (True Negatives - TN) to the total number of benign models: ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘…=Tâ€‹NTâ€‹N+Fâ€‹Nğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ¹ğ‘\mbox{$\mathit{TNR}$}=\frac{TN}{TN+FN}, where FN is False Negatives indicating the number of malicious clients that are wrongly classified as benign.

7 Experimental Results

In this section, we evaluate FLAME against backdoor attacks in the literature (Â§7.1) and demonstrate that our defense mechanism is resilient to adaptive attacksÂ (Â§7.2). In addition, we show the effectiveness of each of FLAMEâ€™s components in Â§B and FLAME overhead in Â§D. Finally, we evaluate the impact of the number of clients (Â§7.3) as well as the degree of non-IID data (Â§7.4).

7.1 Preventing Backdoor Attacks

Effectiveness of FLAME. We evaluate FLAME against the state-of-the-art backdoor attacks called constrain-and-scaleÂ [9], DBAÂ [64], PGD and Edge-CaseÂ [62] and an untargeted poisoning attackÂ [22] (cf.Â Â§F) using the same attack settings as in the original works with multiple datasets. The results are shown in Tab.Â 2. FLAME completely mitigates the constrain-and-scale attack (ğµğ´=0%ğµğ´percent0\mbox{$\mathit{BA}$}=0\%) for all datasets. Moreover, our defense does not affect the Main Task Accuracy (ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘€ğ´\mathit{MA}) of the system as MA reduces by less than 0.4%percent0.40.4\% in all experiments. The DBA attack as well as the Edge-Case attackÂ [62] are also successfully mitigated (ğµğ´=3.2%/4.0%ğµğ´percent3.2percent4.0\mbox{$\mathit{BA}$}=3.2\%/4.0\%). Further, FLAME is also effective against PGD attacks (ğµğ´=0.5%ğµğ´percent0.5\mbox{$\mathit{BA}$}=0.5~{}\%). It should be noted that suggesting words is a quite challenging task, causing the MA even without attack to be only 22.7%, aligned with previous workÂ [9].

We extend our evaluation to various backdoors on three datasets. For NIDS, we evaluate 13 different backdoors (Mirai malware attacks) and 24 device types (78 IoT devices). The results show that FLAME is able to mitigate all backdoor attacks completely while achieving a high MA=99.8%. We evaluate 5 different word backdoors for WP, and 90 different image backdoors for IC, which change the output of a whole class to another class. In all cases, FLAME successfully mitigates the attack while still preserving the ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘€ğ´\mathit{MA}.

Comparison to existing defenses. We compare FLAME to existing defenses: KrumÂ [11], FoolsGoldÂ [25], AurorÂ [56], Adaptive Federated Averaging (AFA) [46], MedianÂ [67] and a generalized differential privacy (DP) approachÂ [9, 44]. Tab.Â 3 shows that FLAME is effective for all 3 datasets, while previous works either fail to mitigate backdoors or reduce the main task accuracy. Krum, FoolsGold, Auror, and AFA do not effectively remove poisoned models and ğµğ´ğµğ´\mathit{BA} often remains at 100%percent100100\%. Also, some defenses make the attack even more successful than without defense. Since they remove many benign updates (cf.Â Â§B) but fail to remove a sufficient number of poisoned updates, these defenses increase the ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘…ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘…\mathit{PMR} and, therefore, also the impact of the attack. Some defenses, e.g., KrumÂ [11], AurorÂ [56] or AFAÂ [46] are not able to handle non-iid data scenarios like Reddit. In contrast, FoolsGold is only effective on the Reddit dataset (ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘…=100%ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘…percent100\mbox{$\mathit{TPR}$}=100\%) because it works well on highly non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) data (cf.Â Â§9). Similarly, AFA only mitigates backdoors on the CIFAR-10 dataset since the data are highly IID (each client is assigned a random set of images) such that the benign models share similar distances to the global model (cf.Â Â§9). Additionally, the modelâ€™s ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘€ğ´\mathit{MA} is negatively impacted.
The DP-based defense is effective, but it significantly reduces ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘€ğ´\mathit{MA}. For example, it performs best on the CIFAR-10 dataset with ğµğ´=0ğµğ´0\mbox{$\mathit{BA}$}=0, but ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘€ğ´\mathit{MA} decreases to 78.9%percent78.978.9\% while FLAME increases ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘€ğ´\mathit{MA} to 91.9%percent91.991.9\% which is close to the benign setting (no attacks), where ğ‘€ğ´=92.2%ğ‘€ğ´percent92.2\mbox{$\mathit{MA}$}=92.2\%.

Effectiveness of FLAMEâ€™s Components. Further, we have also conducted an extensive evaluation of the effectiveness of each of FLAMEâ€™s components. Due to space limitations, we would like to refer to Â§B for the details.

7.2 Resilience to Adaptive Attacks

Given sufficient knowledge about FLAME, an adversary may seek to use adaptive attacks to bypass the defense components. In this section, we analyze such attack scenarios and strategies including changing the injection strategy, model alignment, and model obfuscation.

Changing the Injection Strategy. The adversary ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} may attempt to inject several backdoors simultaneously to execute different attacks on the system in parallel or to circumvent the clustering defense (cf. Â§2.2). FLAME is also effective against such attacks (cf. Fig.Â 5). To further investigate the resilience of FLAME against such attacks, we conduct two experiments: 1) assigning different backdoors to malicious clients and 2) letting each malicious client inject several backdoors. To ensure that each backdoor is injected by a sufficient number of clients, we increased the PMR for this experiment. We conducted these experiments with n=100ğ‘›100n=100 clients of which k=40ğ‘˜40k=40 are malicious on the IoT-Traffic dataset with each type of Mirai attack representing a backdoor. First, we evaluate FLAME for 0,1,20120,1,2, 444, and 888 backdoors, meaning that the number of malicious clients for each backdoor is 0,40,20,10,04020100,40,20,10, and 555. Our experimental results show that our approach is effective in mitigating the attacks as ğµğ´=0%Â±0.0%ğµğ´plus-or-minuspercent0percent0.0\mbox{$\mathit{BA}$}=0\%\pm 0.0\% in all cases, with ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘…=95.2%Â±0.0%ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘…plus-or-minuspercent95.2percent0.0\mbox{$\mathit{TPR}$}=95.2\%\pm 0.0\%, and ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘…=100.0%Â±0.0%ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘…plus-or-minuspercent100.0percent0.0\mbox{$\mathit{TNR}$}=100.0\%\pm 0.0\%. For the second experiment, 4 backdoors are injected by each of the 40 malicious clients. Also, in this case, the results show that FLAME can completely mitigate the backdoors.

Model Alignment. Using the same attack parameter values, i.e., ğ‘ƒğ·ğ‘…ğ‘ƒğ·ğ‘…\mathit{PDR} (cf. Â§2.2), for all malicious clients can result in high distances between benign and poisoned models. Those high distances can be illustrated as a gap between poisoned and benign models, s.t. the clustering can separate them. Therefore, a sophisticated adversary can generate models that bridge the gap between them such that they are merged to the same cluster in our clustering. We evaluate this attack on the IoT-Traffic dataset for k=80ğ‘˜80k=80 malicious clients and n=200ğ‘›200n=200 clients in total. To remove the gap, each malicious client is assigned a random amount of malicious data, i.e., a random ğ‘ƒğ·ğ‘…ğ‘ƒğ·ğ‘…\mathit{PDR} ranging from 5%percent55\% to 20%percent2020\%. As Tab. 4 shows, when we apply model filtering only, our clustering component cannot identify the malicious clients well (ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘…=0%ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘…percent0\mbox{$\mathit{TPR}$}=0\%), resulting in Bâ€‹A=100%ğµğ´percent100BA=100\%. However, when we apply FLAME, although ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘…ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘…\mathit{TPR} remains low (5.68%percent5.685.68\%) FLAME still mitigates the attack successfully (ğµğ´ğµğ´\mathit{BA} reduces from 100%percent100100\% to 0%percent00\%). This can be explained by the fact that when the adversary ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} tunes malicious updates to be close to the benign ones, the attackâ€™s impact is reduced and consequently averaged out by our noising component.

Model Obfuscation. ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} can add noise to the poisoned models to make them difficult to detect. However, our evaluation of such an attack on the IoT-Traffic dataset shows that this strategy is not effective. We evaluate different noise levels to determine a suitable standard deviation for the noise. Thereby, we observe that a noise level of 0.0340.0340.034 causes the modelsâ€™ cosine distances in clustering to change without significantly impacting ğµğ´ğµğ´\mathit{BA}. However, FLAME can still efficiently defend this attack: ğµğ´ğµğ´\mathit{BA} remains at 0%percent00\% and ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘€ğ´\mathit{MA} atÂ 100%.

7.3 Effect of Number of Clients

Impact of Number of Malicious Clients. We assume that the number of benign clients is more than half of all clients (cf.Â Â§2.2) and our clustering is only expected to be successful when ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘…=kn<50%ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘…ğ‘˜ğ‘›percent50\mbox{$\mathit{PMR}$}=\frac{k}{n}<50\% (cf. Â§4.3.1). We evaluate FLAME for different ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘…ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘…\mathit{PMR} values. FigureÂ 7 shows how ğµğ´ğµğ´\mathit{BA}, ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘…ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘…\mathit{TPR}, and ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘…\mathit{TNR} change in the IC, NIDS, and WP applications for ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘…ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘…\mathit{PMR} values from 25%percent2525\% to 60%percent6060\%. It shows that FLAME is only effective if ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘…<50%ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘…percent50\mbox{$\mathit{PMR}$}<50\% so that only benign clients are admitted to the model aggregation (ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘…=100%ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘…percent100\mbox{$\mathit{TNR}$}=100\%) and thus ğµğ´=0%ğµğ´percent0\mbox{$\mathit{BA}$}=0\%. However, if ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘…>50%ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘…percent50\mbox{$\mathit{PMR}$}>50\%, FLAME fails to mitigate the attack because the majority of poisoned models will be included resulting in low ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘…\mathit{TNR}. Interestingly, FLAME accepted all models for ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘…=50%ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘…percent50\mbox{$\mathit{PMR}$}=50\% (ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘…=0%ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘…percent0\mbox{$\mathit{TPR}$}=0\% and ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘…=100%ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘…percent100\mbox{$\mathit{TNR}$}=100\%). For the IC application, since the IC data are non-IID, poisoned models are not similar. Therefore, some poisoned models were excluded from the cluster resulting in a high ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘…ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘…\mathit{TPR} even for ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘…ğ‘ ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘…ğ‘ \mathit{PMRs} higher than 50%. However, the majority of poisoned models were selected resulting in the drop in the ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘…\mathit{TNR}.

Varying number of clients in different training rounds. In general, FLAME is a round-independent defense, i.e., it does not use information from previous rounds such as which clients were excluded in which rounds. Therefore, FLAME will not be affected if the number of clients or number of malicious clients varies as long as the majority of clients remain benign. To demonstrate this, we simulate realistic scenarios in which clients can join and drop out dynamically. We conducted an experiment where during each round, the total number of available clients is randomly selected. As the result, the number of malicious clients will also be random. In this experiment, we used a population of 100 clients in total, out of which 25 are malicious. In each round, a random number (from 60 to 90) of clients are selected, so that the fraction of malicious clients (ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘…ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘…\mathit{PMR}) varies in each round. FigureÂ 8 shows the experimental results. One can see that the proportion of malicious clients (ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘…ğ‘ƒğ‘€ğ‘…\mathit{PMR}) does not affect the effectiveness of FLAME, i.e., the backdoor is completely removed (Bâ€‹A=0%ğµğ´percent0BA=0\%) in every round. Since all poisoned models are detected, their negative effect on the aggregated model is removed. Therefore, the MA with FLAME is better than the one without defense, and is almost always 100Â % aligned with the results in Tab. 3.

7.4 Impact of the Degree of non-IID Data

Since clustering is based on measuring differences between benign and malicious updates, the distribution of data among clients might affect our defense. We conduct two experiments for both Constrain-and-scale and Edge-Case PGD on the CIFAR-10 dataset. For Reddit and IoT datasets, changing the degree of non-IID data is not meaningful since the data have a natural distribution as every client obtains data from different Reddit users or traffic chunks from different IoT devices. Following previous worksÂ [22, 62], we vary the degree of non-IID data DegnIIDsubscriptDegnIID\text{Deg}_{\text{nIID}}by changing the fraction of images belonging to a specific class assigned to clients. In particular, we divide the clients into 10 groups corresponding to the 10 classes of CIFAR-10. The clients of each group are assigned a fixed fraction of DegnIIDsubscriptDegnIID\text{Deg}_{\text{nIID}}of the images from its designated image class, while the rest of the images will be assigned to it at random. Consequently, the data distribution is random, i.e., completely IID if DegnIID=0%subscriptDegnIIDpercent0\text{Deg}_{\text{nIID}}=0\% (all images are randomly assigned) and completely non-IID if DegnIID=100%subscriptDegnIIDpercent100\text{Deg}_{\text{nIID}}=100\% (a client only gets images from its designated class).

FigureÂ 9a shows the evaluation results for the constrain-and-scale attacks. Although FLAME does not detect the poisoned models for very non-IID scenarios, it still mitigates the attack as the BA remains 0%percent00\% for all values of DegnIIDsubscriptDegnIID\text{Deg}_{\text{nIID}}. For low DegnIIDsubscriptDegnIID\text{Deg}_{\text{nIID}}, FLAME effectively identifies the poisoned models (Tâ€‹Nâ€‹R=100%ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘…percent100TNR=100\%) and the MA remains on almost the same level as without defense. As shown in Fig.Â 9b, FLAME also mitigates the Edge-Case PGD attack effectively for all Î±ğ›¼\alpha values of the Dirichlet distribution and the MA also stays on the same level as without defense. However, since not all poisoned models are detected, a higher Ïƒğœ\sigma is determined dynamically to mitigate the constrain-and-scale backdoor, resulting in a slightly reduced MA for DegnIIDâ‰¥0.7subscriptDegnIID0.7\text{Deg}_{\text{nIID}}\geq 0.7 (MA is 91.9%percent91.991.9\% for DegnIID=0.6subscriptDegnIID0.6\text{Deg}_{\text{nIID}}=0.6, and is reduced to 91.0%percent91.091.0\% for DegnIID=1.0subscriptDegnIID1.0\text{Deg}_{\text{nIID}}=1.0). Note that Fig.Â 9 shows the evaluation results in a training round tğ‘¡t where the global model Gtsubscriptğºğ‘¡G_{t} is close to convergence [9], thus even though the TNR decreases with a large value of DegnIIDsubscriptDegnIID\text{Deg}_{\text{nIID}}, the drop of MA with FLAME is not substantial.

8 Privacy-preserving Federated Learning

A number of attacks on FL have been proposed that aim to infer from parameters of a model the presence of a specific training sample in the training dataset (membership inference attacks)Â [51, 57, 45], properties of training samples (property inference attacks)Â [26, 45], try to assess the proportion of samples of a specific class in the data (distribution estimation attacks)Â [63]. Inference attacks by the aggregatorÂ ğ’œssuperscriptğ’œğ‘ \mathcal{A}^{s} are significantly stronger, as ğ’œssuperscriptğ’œğ‘ \mathcal{A}^{s} has access to the local modelsÂ [47] and can also link gained information to a specific user, while the global model anonymizes the individual contributions. Therefore, enhanced privacy protection for FL is needed that prohibits access to the local model updates.

Adversary Model (privacy). In this adversary type, ğ’œssuperscriptğ’œğ‘ {\mathcal{A}^{s}} attempts to infer sensitive information about clientsâ€™ dataÂ Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i} from their model updatesÂ Wisubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–W_{i}Â [51, 57, 26, 45] by maximizing the information Ï•i=Inferâ€‹(Wi)subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–Infersubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–\phi_{i}=\textsc{Infer}(W_{i}) that ğ’œssuperscriptğ’œğ‘ {\mathcal{A}^{s}} gains about the data Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i} of clientÂ iğ‘–i by inferring from its corresponding modelÂ Wisubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–W_{i}.

Deficiencies of existing defenses. Generally, there are two approaches to protect the privacy of clientsâ€™ data: differential privacy (DP;Â [20]) and cryptographic techniques such as homomorphic encryptionÂ [27] or multi-party computationÂ [16]. DP is a statistical approach that can be efficiently implemented, but it can only offer high privacy protection at the cost of a significant loss in accuracy due to the noise added to the modelsÂ [68, 8]. In contrast, cryptographic techniques provide strong privacy guarantees as well as high accuracy at the cost of reduced efficiency.

Private FLAME. To securely implement FLAME using STPC, we use an optimized combination of three prominent STPC techniques as implemented with state-of-the-art optimizations in the ABY frameworkÂ [16]. Fig.Â 10 shows an overview of privateÂ FLAME. It involves nğ‘›n clients and two non-colluding servers, called aggregator Ağ´A and external serverÂ BğµB. Each clientÂ iâˆˆ{1,â€¦,n}ğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘›i\in\{1,...,n\} splits the parameters of its local update Wisubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–W_{i} into two Arithmetic shares âŸ¨XâŸ©iAsubscriptsuperscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘‹ğ´ğ‘–\langle X\rangle^{A}_{i} and âŸ¨XâŸ©iBsubscriptsuperscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘‹ğµğ‘–\langle X\rangle^{B}_{i}, such that Wi=âŸ¨XâŸ©iA+âŸ¨XâŸ©iBsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ´superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘‹ğ‘–ğµW_{i}=\langle X\rangle_{i}^{A}+\langle X\rangle_{i}^{B}, and sends âŸ¨XâŸ©iAsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ´\langle X\rangle_{i}^{A} to Ağ´A and âŸ¨XâŸ©iBsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘‹ğ‘–ğµ\langle X\rangle_{i}^{B} to BğµB. Ağ´A and BğµB then privately compute the new global model via STPC. We co-design the distance calculation, clustering, adaptive clipping, and aggregation of FLAME (cf.Â Alg.Â 1) of FLAME as efficient STPC protocols.To further improve performance, we approximate HDBSCAN with the simpler DBSCAN [12] to avoid the construction of the minimal spanning tree in HDBSCAN as it is very expensive to realize with STPC. SeeÂ Â§G for more details on private FLAME evaluation of its accuracy and performance.

9 Related Work

In general, existing backdoor defenses can roughly be divided into two main categories. The first one aims to distinguish malicious updates and benign updates by 1) clustering model updates [56, 25, 11, 17, 37, 32, 38], 2) changing aggregation rules [67, 28], and 3) using root dataset [6]. The second category is based on differential privacy techniques [61, 9]. Next, we will discuss these points in detail.

Clustering model updates. Several backdoor defenses, such as KrumÂ [11], AFAÂ [46], and AurorÂ [56], aim at separating benign and malicious model updates. However, they only work under specific assumptions about the underlying data distributions, e.g., Auror and Krum assume that data of benign clients are iid. In contrast, FoolsGold and AFA [46] assume that benign data are non-iid. In addition, FoolsGold assumes that manipulated data are iid. As a result, these defenses are only effective under specific circumstances (cf.Â Â§7.1) and cannot handle the simultaneous injection of multiple backdoors (cf.Â Â§4.3.1). Moreover, such defenses cannot detect stealthy attacks, e.g., where the adversary constrains their poisoned updates within benign update distribution such as Constrain-and-scale attacks [9]. In contrast, FLAME does not make any assumption about the data distribution, clipping, and noising components can also mitigate stealthy attacks, and FLAME can defend against injection of multiple backdoorsÂ (cf.Â Â§4.3.1).

Changing aggregation rules. Instead of using FedAvg [42], Yin etÂ al.Â [67] and Guerraoui etÂ al.Â [28] propose using the median parameters from all local models as the global model parameters, i.e., Gt=Medianâ€‹(W1t,â€¦,Wnt)subscriptğºğ‘¡Mediansubscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šğ‘¡1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šğ‘¡ğ‘›G_{t}=\textsc{Median}(W^{t}_{1},\ldots,W^{t}_{n}). However, the adversary can bypass it by injecting stealthy models like W3â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šâ€²3W^{\prime}_{3} (cf. Fig. 2), in which the parameters of the poisoned model will be selected to be incorporated into the global model. Further, our evaluation in Â§7.1 shows that Median also reduces the performance of the model significantly.

Using root data. Although FLTrustÂ [14] can defend against byzantine clients (with arbitrary behavior) and detect poisoning attacks, including backdoors, it requires the aggregator to have access to a benign root dataset. BaffleÂ [6] utilizes clients using their own data to evaluate the performance of the aggregated model to detect backdoors. However, this approach has several limitations. Firstly, the backdoor triggers are only known to the attacker. One cannot ensure that the benign clients would have such trigger data to activate the backdoor. Secondly, Baffle does not work in a non-IID data scenario with a small number of clients as clients cannot distinguish deficits in model performance due to the backdoor from lack of data.

Differential Privacy-based approaches. Clipping and noising are known techniques to achieve differential privacy (DP)Â [20]. However, directly applying these techniques to defend against backdoor attacks is not effective because they significantly decrease the Main Task Accuracy (Â§7.1) [9]. FLAME tackles this by i) identifying and filtering out potential poisoned models that have a high attack impact (cf.Â Â§4.3.1), and ii) eliminating the residual poison with an appropriate adaptive clipping bound and noise level, such that the Main Task Accuracy is retained (cf.Â Â§4.3.2).

10 Revisiting Attacks Claiming to Bypass FLAME

Since we presented our FLAME paper at the USENIX Security Conference in 2022 [49], it has sparked considerable interest among researchers, garnering over 100 citations according to Google Scholar [1]. When creating this document, two attacks have been highlighted that allege to circumvent FLAME [36, 65]. We promptly responded by conducting an exhaustive investigation into these attacks, uncovering notable errors in their approach. They made misleading claims and seemed to misinterpret FLAMEâ€™s core design principles. To resolve this issue, we initiated a dialogue with the respective authors, leading to an acknowledgment and ensuing correction of assertions by Xu et al. [65]. In the subsequent sections, we explore these studies in greater detail.

Xu et al. [65] propose a distributed backdoor attack (DBA) targeting federated Graph Neural Networks (GNN) training. The authors assert their proposed attacks can circumvent FLAME [49]. However, upon discussing this with the authors of [65], it becomes clear that they have misinterpreted our approach and failed to incorporate all key components of FLAME in their understanding. Specifically, they have only accounted for the clustering aspect of FLAME while neglecting the Adaptive Clipping and Noising components, both of which are essential for backdoor mitigation. Acknowledging this, the authors have revised their claim in the recent version of their paper published on arXiv [66].

Li et al. [36] introduce 3DFed , a multifaceted backdoor attack composed of three elements: Constrain Loss, Noise Masks, and Decoy Model. Among these, the Constrain Loss component is crafted to target FLAME. However, it solely aims to counteract the Clipping defense facet of FLAME, as outlined in Â§VI of [36]. This implies that the authors did not account for the Clustering and Noising elements intrinsic to our defense design. At its core, 3DFed seeks to limit the loss during the backdoor model training phase, striving to keep the backdoor objective closely aligned with the global model in terms of L2-norm (Euclidean distance). This alignment is achieved by manipulating the hyper-parameter Î²ğ›½\beta, meaning 3DFed â€™s goal is to ensure the L2-norm of the backdoor model falls under the L2-norm-based clipping threshold. In [36], however, the authors neither discuss nor assess how hyper-parameter Î²ğ›½\beta could be selected to ensure L2-norms of backdoored models fall below our dynamic Clipping boundary. It is important to note that because the Clipping threshold in FLAME is dynamically recalculated with each federated training iteration, itâ€™s highly unlikely that a particular Î²ğ›½\beta value can ensure the L2-norms of tampered models stay below our dynamic Clipping threshold while still maintaining the attackâ€™s effectiveness. This is particularly true once Gaussian noise is factored in. As we highlighted in Section 4, we are aware of such tampered models, working on the assumption that an adversary can carefully manipulate the training process (see Constrain-and-scale attack [9]). Consequently, we argue that 3DFed cannot counteract FLAME. To empirically support this argument, we have carried out a comprehensive replication study of 3DFed using the exact source code provided by the 3DFed authors [4], strictly adhering to the experimental setup detailed in the 3DFed paper [36], as described in Section H. As anticipated, contrary to the results presented in the 3DFed paper, specifically Figures 10c, 10h, and 13c [36], our results demonstrate FLAMEâ€™s effective mitigation of 3DFed attacks across all datasets used in 3DFed experiments (see Table 7).

In conclusion, Table 5 underscores the significant discrepancy between how recent attacks interpret FLAME and the actual design principles of FLAME. Importantly, none of these approaches consider the Adaptive Noising defense, which plays a crucial role in eliminating remaining backdoor updates. This highlights the essentiality of comprehending design principles when devising an attack against FLAME.

11 Conclusion

In this paper, we introduce FLAME, a resilient aggregation framework for FL that eliminates the impact of backdoor attacks while maintaining the performance of the aggregated model on the main task. We propose a method to approximate the amount of noise that needs to be injected into the global model to neutralize backdoors. Furthermore, in combination with our dynamic clustering and adaptive clipping, FLAME can significantly reduce the noise scale for backdoor removal and thus preserve the benign performance of the global model. In addition, we design, implement, and benchmark efficient secure two-party computation protocols for FLAME to ensure the privacy of clientsâ€™ training data and to impede inference attacks on client updates.

Appendix A Datasets and Learning Configurations

Word Prediction (WP). We use the Reddit dataset of November 2017 [2] with the same settings as state-of-the-art works [9, 42, 44] for comparability. In particular, each user in the dataset with at least 150 posts and not more than 500 posts is considered as a client. This results in 80â€‰000 clientsâ€™ datasets with sizes between 298 and 32â€‰660 words.

The model consists of two LSTM layers and a linear output layer [9, 42]. To be comparable to the attack setting inÂ [9], we evaluate FLAME on five different backdoors, each with a different trigger sentence corresponding to a chosen output.

Image Classification (IC). For image classification, we use mainly the CIFAR-10 datasetÂ [34], a standard benchmark dataset for image classification, in particular for FLÂ [42] and backdoor attacksÂ [9, 10, 46]. It consists of 60â€‰000 images of 10 different classes. The adversary aims at changing the predicted label of one class of images to another class of images. We use a lightweight version of the ResNet18 modelÂ [29] with 4 convolutional layers with max-pooling and batch normalizationÂ [9]. The experimental setup consists of 100 clients and uses a PMR of 20%percent2020\%. In addition to the CIFAR-10 dataset, we also evaluate FLAMEâ€™s effectiveness on two further datasets for image classification. The MNIST dataset consists of 70â€‰000 handwritten digitsÂ [35]. The learning task is to classify images to identify digits. The adversary poisons the model by mislabeling labels of digit images before using it for training [56]. We use a convolutional neural network (CNN) with 431000 parameters. The Tiny-ImageNet 333https://tiny-imagenet.herokuapp.com consists of 200 classes and each class has 500 training images, 50 validation images, and 50 test images. We used ResNet18Â [29] model.

Network Intrusion Detection System (NIDS). We test backdoor attacks on IoT anomaly-based intrusion detection systems that often represent critical security applicationsÂ [7, 30, 18, 60, 33, 48, 50]. Here, the adversary aims at causing incorrect classification of anomalous traffic patterns, e.g., generated by IoT malware, as benign patterns. Based on the FL anomaly detection system DÃoT Â [48], we use three datasets called DIoT-Benign, DIoT-Attack, and UNSW-BenignÂ [48, 58] from real-world home and office deployments (four homes and two offices located in Germany and Australia). DIoT-Attack contains the traffic of 5 anomalously behaving IoT devices, infected by the Mirai malwareÂ [48]. Moreover, we collected a fourth IoT dataset containing communication data from 24 typical IoT devices (including IP cameras and power plugs) in three different smart home settings and an office setting. FollowingÂ [48], we extracted device-type-specific datasets capturing the devicesâ€™ communication behavior. We simulate the FL setup by splitting each device typeâ€™s dataset among several clients (from 20 to 200). Each client has a training dataset corresponding to three hours of traffic measurements containing samples of roughly 2â€‰000-3â€‰000 communication packets. The learning model consists of 2 GRU layers and a fully connected layer.

Appendix B Effectiveness of FLAMEâ€™s Components

B.1 Effectiveness of the Clustering Component

We show the results for the clustering component in Tab.Â 6. Appendix C NaÃ¯ve Combination

Furthermore, we test a naÃ¯ve combination of the defense components by stacking clipping and adding noise (using a fixed clipping bound of 1.0 and a standard deviation of 0.01 as in [9]) on top of a clustering component using K-means. However, this naÃ¯ve approach still allows a ğµğ´ğµğ´\mathit{BA} of 51.9% and a ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘€ğ´\mathit{MA} of 60.24%, compared to a ğµğ´ğµğ´\mathit{BA} of 0.0% and a ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘€ğ´\mathit{MA} of 89.87% of FLAME in the same scenario for the CIFAR-10 dataset. Based on our evaluations in Â§3, it becomes apparent that FLAMEâ€™s dynamic nature goes beyond previously proposed defenses that consist of static baseline ideas, which FLAME significantly optimizes, extends, and automates to offer a comprehensive dynamic and private defense against sophisticated backdoor attacks.

Appendix D Overhead of FLAME

We evaluated FLAME for 6 different device types from the IoT dataset. In this experiment, only benign clients participated and the model was randomly initialized. The highest observed overhead was 4 additional rounds. In average, 1.671.671.67 additional training rounds were needed to achieve at least 99% of the ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘€ğ´\mathit{MA} that was achieved without applying the defense, i.e., FLAME does not prevent the model from converging.

Appendix E HDBSCAN

HDBSCANÂ [13] is a density-based clustering technique that classifies data samples in different clusters without predefined the maximum distance and the number of clusters. In the following, we describe HDBSCAN in detail, following the implementation of McInnes etÂ al.Â Â [40, 41]. However, we focus on the behavior of HDBSCAN for the parameters that FLAME uses, i.e., when min_cluster_size=N/2+1ğ‘21\nicefrac{{N}}{{2}}+1 and min_samples=1, e.g., because of the choice for min_cluster_size we skip parts that deal with multiple clusters. HDBSCAN first uses the given distances to build a minimal spanning tree (MST), where the vertices represent the individual data points and the edges are weighted by the distances between the respective points. Then it uses the MST to build a binary tree where the leaf nodes represent the vertices of the MST and the non-leaf nodes represent the edges of the MST. For this, first, all vertices are considered as separate trees (of size 1). For this, first, all vertices are considered as separate trees (of size 1) and then, starting from the edge with the lowest weight, iteratively the trees are merged by creating a non-leaf-node for each edge of the MST and set the (previously not connected) subtrees containing the endpoints of the edge as children for the new node (represented by calling the function make_binary_tree. In the next step, HDBSCAN collects all nodes of the binary tree as candidates, that cover at least N/2+1ğ‘21\nicefrac{{N}}{{2}}+1 data points. Since only non-leaf nodes fulfill the requirement of covering at least N/2+1ğ‘21\nicefrac{{N}}{{2}}+1 data points, each cluster candidate is based on a node, representing an edge in the MST. It uses the weight of the edge and the number of covered points to calculate a so-called stability value. Then HDBSCAN uses the stability value to determine the cluster candidate with the most homogeneous density and returns this candidate as majority cluster. Finally, it assigns the cluster label to all data points inside this cluster and labels all points outside of this cluster as noise.

Appendix F Effectiveness of FLAME against untargeted poisoning attacks

Another attack type related to backdooring is untargeted poisoningÂ [22, 11, 10]. Unlike backdoor attacks that aim to incorporate specific backdoor functionalities, untargeted poisoning aims at rendering the model unusable. The adversary uses crafted local models with low Main Task Accuracy to damage the global model GğºG. Fang at el.[22] propose such an attack bypassing state-of-the-art defenses. Although we do not focus on untargeted poisoning, our approach intuitively defends it since, in principle, this attack also trade-offs attack impact against stealthiness. To evaluate the effectiveness of FLAME against this attack, we test the Krum-based attack proposed by [22] on FLAME. Since [22]â€™s evaluation uses image datasets, we evaluate FLAMEâ€™s resilience against it with CIFAR-10. The evaluation results show that although the attack significantly damages the model by reducing ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘€ğ´\mathit{MA} from 92.16%percent92.1692.16\% to 46.72%percent46.7246.72\%, FLAME can successfully defend against it and ğ‘€ğ´ğ‘€ğ´\mathit{MA} remains at 91.31%percent91.3191.31\%.

Appendix G Performance of Private FLAME

For our implementation, we use the STPC framework ABYÂ [16] which implements the three sharing types, including state-of-the-art optimizations and flexible conversions and the open-source privacy-preserving DBSCAN by Bozdemir et al.Â [12]. All STPC results are averaged over 10 experiments and run on two separate servers with Intel Core i9-7960X CPUs with 2.8 GHz and 128 GB RAM connected over a 10 Gbit/s LAN with 0.2 ms RTT.

Approximating HDBSCAN by DBSCAN. We measure the effect of approximating HDBSCAN by DBSCAN including the binary search for the neighborhood parameter Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. The results show that our approximation has a negligible loss of accuracy. For some applications, the approximation even performs slightly better than the standard FLAME, e.g., for CIFAR-10, private FLAME correctly filters all poisoned models, while standard FLAME accepts a small number (ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘…=86.2%ğ‘‡ğ‘ğ‘…percent86.2\mbox{$\mathit{TNR}$}=86.2\%), which is still sufficient to achieve ğµğ´=0.0%ğµğ´percent0.0\mbox{$\mathit{BA}$}=0.0\%.

Runtime of Private FLAME. We evaluate the runtime in seconds per training iteration of the cosine distance, Euclidean distance + clipping + model aggregation, and clustering steps of Alg.Â 1 in standard (without STPC) and in private FLAME (with STPC). The results show that private FLAME causes a significant overhead on the runtime by a factor of up to three orders of magnitude compared to the standard (non-private) FLAME. However, even if we consider the largest model (Reddit) with K=100ğ¾100K=100 clients, we have a total server-side runtime of 22â€‰081.65 seconds (â‰ˆ\approx 6 hours) for a training iteration with STPC. Such runtime overhead would be acceptable to maintain privacy, especially since mobile phones, which would be a typical type of clients in FLÂ [42], are not always available and connected so that there will be delays in synchronizing clientsâ€™ model updates in FL. These delays can then also be used to run STPC. Furthermore, achieving provable privacy by using STPC may even motivate more clients to contribute to FL in the first place and provide more data.

Appendix H Replication Study of 3DFed

To ensure consistency with 3DFed work, we used the exact source code provided by 3DFed authors [4] and thoroughly followed the experimental setup described in 3DFed paper [36]. Every aspect, from hyper-parameter selection to training regime configuration, was carefully implemented. We repeated each experiment a minimum of 50 times to ensure robustness and reliability. To introduce variability, we employed various random seed values in each experiment. This rigorous process was applied to four distinct pre-trained models, each reaching different convergence levels based on the number of training epochs. Our experimental results, summarized in Tab. 7, primarily focus on two key metrics: Backdoor Accuracy (BA) and Main-task Accuracy (MA). The findings undeniably establish the effectiveness of Flame in mitigating 3DFed attacks. As the global model approaches convergence, a significant reduction in BA is observed, indicating that the BA closely resemble those obtained through random guesses.
